Here is the problem with the whole 'fairy tale' argument against religion. 
 
 In the absence of very clear and obvious evidence on any historical event or figure (and there are many such examples), what truly determines whether or not something has "fairy tale status" or not is whether or not a great many people believe it to be true. Until it is clearly disproven that the evidence we have (the synoptic biogrphapical writings about Jesus) is not true, then I don't see how we can honestly give it fairy tale status. No one truly believes the tooth fairy is real. (Well, except maybe for some little children.) But billions--yes billions of people--believe that there is a God and many believe they have experienced it in some way to some degree. On that discrepancy alone, the comparison is rendered invalid. And last time I checked, there aren't ancient references, and entire corroborating books written about the tooth fairy living his life.
 
 On the otherhand, let's take an example from history that has about the same degree of evidence as Jesus: Egyptian pharoahs of which we only know of from Egyptian temple writings. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pharaohs) Take "Amenemhat I" for instance, from the Middle Kingdom of Egypt. Now, we have no mummy. No body has been found--no physical evidence. We do have an old pyramid attributed to him, though we can't know for certain, it was so long ago. However we do have him written about in religious-laden writings from the ancient era. So, it seems that in this case, experts aren't apt to call this pharoah a fairy tale, yet people will jump at calling Jesus a fairy tale on approximately the same level of evidence we have for this pharoah. In fact, there are pharoahs accepted to have existed on the basis of far less evidence than we have for Amenemhat. But using the approach to evidence toward Pharoahs that critics of Christianity sometimes use toward Christ, then we'd have to call MOST of the pharoahs "fairy tales". 
 
 It seems to me that this is a case of "fairy tale status" getting applied simply because some are determined to oppose the idea of religion.
